'''Robert Donald Teare''', [[Royal College of Physicians|FRCP]], [[Royal College of Pathologists|FRCPath]] (1 July 1911 – 17 January 1979) was a senior British [[pathologist]]. ==Early life== Teare was born 1 July 1911, and educated at [[King William's College]] on the [[Isle of Man]], and [[Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge]]. He trained at [[St George's, University of London|St George's Hospital, London]] from where he qualified in 1936.
==Career== Teare began his career as a lecturer in forensic medicine at [[Barts and The London School of Medicine and Dentistry|St Bartholomew's Hospital Medical College]]. In 1963 he became reader and eventually professor of forensic medicine at [[Charing Cross Hospital|Charing Cross Hospital Medical School]], a post he held until retirement in 1975. Teare was also a lecturer at the [[Hendon Police College|Metropolitan Police College]], Hendon, and served as President of the [[Medical Defence Union]]. He was also a Fellow of the [[Royal College of Physicians]] and of the [[Royal College of Pathologists]]. Teare also served as President of the British Association of Forensic Medicine. In 1973, Teare carried out the [[autopsy]] on [[Bruce Lee]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_FQuAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hn0FAAAAIBAJ&pg=4578,2216339&dq=donald-teare+bruce-lee&hl=en | title=British professor testifies: Bruce's death not caused by marijuana | date=20 September 1973 | journal=[[New Straits Times]] }}</ref>
Together with [[Keith Simpson (pathologist)|Keith Simpson]] and [[Francis Camps]], Teare was one of the "Three Musketeers", who dealt with almost all the suspicious deaths in the London area.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/8446356/Professor-David-Bowen.html | journal=[[Sunday Telegraph]] | title=Professor David Bowen | date=12 April 2011 }}</ref>
Professor Teare was called to give evidence in many high profile criminal investigations, such as the murder of Beryl Evans and her baby Geraldine in the [[Timothy Evans]] case. Although Evans was convicted and hanged, three years later the real killer, [[John Reginald Christie]] confessed to the crimes and many others. He was hanged, and after many enquiries, Evans was declared innocent of the crime for which he had been hanged. Teare's accident investigations included the horrific [[Harrow and Wealdstone rail crash]] which occurred in 1952 killing 112 people.{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}}
Teare retired in 1975 and died 17 January 1979 on the Isle of Man.
